contentrichtext.text: {{One source|date=February 2012}} {{No footnotes|date=February 2012}} [[File:Eugénie de Guérin.jpg|thumb|Eugénie de Guérin.]] '''Eugénie de Guérin''' (January 29, 1805 – May 31, 1848), [[France|French]] [[writer]], was the sister of the [[poet]] [[Maurice de Guérin]]. Her ''Journals'' (1861, Eng. trans., 1865) and her ''Lettres'' (1864, Eng. trans., 1865) indicated the possession of gifts of as rare an order as those of her brother, though of a somewhat different kind. In her case [[mysticism]] assumed a form more strictly religious, and she continued to mourn her brother's loss of his early [[Roman Catholicism|Catholic]] faith. Five years older than he, she cherished a love for him which was blended with a somewhat motherly anxiety. After his death she began the collection and publication of the scattered fragments of his writings. She died, however, before her task was completed. See [[Charles Augustin Sainte-Beuve|Sainte-Beuve]], ''Causeries du lundi'' (vol. xii.) and ''Nouveaux Lundis'' (vol. iii.); G Merlet, ''Causeries sur les femmes et les hIres'' (Paris, 1865); Selden, ''L'Esprit des femmes de notre temps'' (Paris, 1864); Marelle, ''Eugénie et Maurice de Guérin'' (Berlin, 1869); [[Harriet Parr]], ''M. and E. de Guérin'', a monograph (London, 1870); and [[Matthew Arnold]]'s essays on Maurice and Eugénie de Guérin, in his ''Essays in Criticism''. ==References== *{{1911}} ==Suggested reading== * Guérin, Eugénie de.
